speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: So desperate thieves, all hopeless of their lives,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Breathe out invectives gainst the officers.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O Clifford, but bethink thee once again,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And in thy thought oer-run my former time;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, if though canst for blushing, view this face,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And bite thy tongue, that slanders him with cowardice

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I will not bandy with thee word for word,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: But buckle with thee blows, twice two for one.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hold, valiant Clifford! for a thousand causes

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I would prolong awhile the traitors life.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Wrath makes him deaf: speak thou, Northumberland.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Hold, Clifford! do not honour him so much

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: What valour were it, when a cur doth grin,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: For one to thrust his hand between his teeth,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: When he might spurn him with his foot away?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: It is wars prize to take all vantages;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And ten to one is no impeach of valour.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: They lay hands on YORK, who struggles

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: So doth the cony struggle in the net.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So triumph thieves upon their conquerd booty;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So true men yield, with robbers so oermatchd.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: What would your grace have done unto him now?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Come, make him stand upon this molehill here,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That raught at mountains with outstretched arms,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet parted but the shadow with his hand.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What! was it you that would be Englands king?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Wast you that revelld in our parliament,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And made a preachment of your high descent?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Where are your mess of sons to back you now?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The wanton Edward, and the lusty George?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And wheres that valiant crook-back prodigy,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Look, York: I staind this napkin with the blood

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That valiant Clifford, with his rapiers point,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Made issue from the bosom of the boy;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And if thine eyes can water for his death,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I give thee this to dry thy cheeks withal.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Alas poor York! but that I hate thee deadly,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I should lament thy miserable state.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I prithee, grieve, to make me merry, York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What, hath thy fiery heart so parchd thine entrails

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That not a tear can fall for Rutlands death?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why art thou patient, man? thou shouldst be mad;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And I, to make thee mad, do mock thee thus.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stamp, rave, and fret, that I may sing and dance.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou wouldst be feed, I see, to make me sport:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: York cannot speak, unless he wear a crown.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A crown for York! and, lords, bow low to him:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hold you his hands, whilst I do set it on.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Putting a paper crown on his head

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, marry, sir, now looks he like a king!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, this is he that took King Henrys chair,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And this is he was his adopted heir.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But how is it that great Plantagenet

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Is crownd so soon, and broke his solemn oath?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As I bethink me, you should not be king

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And will you pale your head in Henrys glory,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And rob his temples of the diadem,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Now in his life, against your holy oath?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, tis a fault too too unpardonable!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Off with the crown, and with the crown his head;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And, whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: That is my office, for my fathers sake.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Nay, stay; lets hear the orisons he makes.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose tongue more poisons than the adders tooth!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To triumph, like an Amazonian trull,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Upon their woes whom fortune captivates!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Made impudent with use of evil deeds,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thy father bears the type of King of Naples,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of both the Sicils and Jerusalem,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Yet not so wealthy as an English yeoman.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hath that poor monarch taught thee to insult?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: It needs not, nor it boots thee not, proud queen,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Unless the adage must be verified,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That beggars mounted run their horse to death.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But, God he knows, thy share thereof is small:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Tis virtue that doth make them most admired;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The contrary doth make thee wonderd at:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Tis government that makes them seem divine;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The want thereof makes thee abominable:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou art as opposite to every good

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As the Antipodes are unto us,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Or as the south to the septentrion.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O tigers heart wrapt in a womans hide!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: How couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To bid the father wipe his eyes withal,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And yet be seen to bear a womans face?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Women are soft, mild, pitiful and flexible;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Bidst thou me rage? why, now thou hast thy wish:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Wouldst have me weep? why, now thou hast thy will:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For raging wind blows up incessant showers,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And when the rage allays, the rain begins.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: These tears are my sweet Rutlands obsequies:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And every drop cries vengeance for his death,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Gainst thee, fell Clifford, and thee, false

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Frenchwoman.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Beshrew me, but his passion moves me so

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That hardly can I cheque my eyes from tears.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That face of his the hungry cannibals

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Would not have touchd, would not have staind with blood:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But you are more inhuman, more inexorable,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, ten times more, than tigers of Hyrcania.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: See, ruthless queen, a hapless fathers tears:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This cloth thou dipdst in blood of my sweet boy,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And I with tears do wash the blood away.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Keep thou the napkin, and go boast of this:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And if thou tellst the heavy story right,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Upon my soul, the hearers will shed tears;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Yea even my foes will shed fast-falling tears,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And say Alas, it was a piteous deed!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: There, take the crown, and, with the crown, my curse;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And in thy need such comfort come to thee

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As now I reap at thy too cruel hand!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the world:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: I should not for my life but weep with him.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What, weeping-ripe, my Lord Northumberland?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Think but upon the wrong he did us all,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And that will quickly dry thy melting tears.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Heres for my oath, heres for my fathers death.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Stabbing him

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And heres to right our gentle-hearted king.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stabbing him

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Dies

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Off with his head, and set it on York gates;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: So York may overlook the town of York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: SCENE I. A plain near Mortimers Cross in Herefordshire.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A march. Enter EDWARD, RICHARD, and their power

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I wonder how our princely father scaped,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Or whether he be scaped away or no

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: From Cliffords and Northumberlands pursuit:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had he been taen, we should have heard the news;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had he been slain, we should have heard the news;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Or had he scaped, methinks we should have heard

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: The happy tidings of his good escape.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: How fares my brother? why is he so sad?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I cannot joy, until I be resolved

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Where our right valiant father is become.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I saw him in the battle range about;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And watchd him how he singled Clifford forth.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Methought he bore him in the thickest troop

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As doth a lion in a herd of neat;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or as a bear, encompassd round with dogs,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who having pinchd a few and made them cry,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So fared our father with his enemies;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So fled his enemies my warlike father:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Methinks, tis prize enough to be his son.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See how the morning opes her golden gates,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And takes her farewell of the glorious sun!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: How well resembles it the prime of youth,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Trimmd like a younker prancing to his love!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Not separated with the racking clouds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But severd in a pale clear-shining sky.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See, see! they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As if they vowd some league inviolable:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: In this the heaven figures some event.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I think it cites us, brother, to the field,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Each one already blazing by our meeds,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Should notwithstanding join our lights together

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And over-shine the earth as this the world.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whateer it bodes, henceforward will I bear

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Upon my target three fair-shining suns.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: You love the breeder better than the male.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ah, one that was a woful looker-on

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: When as the noble Duke of York was slain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your princely father and my loving lord!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Environed he was with many foes,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And stood against them, as the hope of Troy

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Against the Greeks that would have enterd Troy.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But Hercules himself must yield to odds;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And many strokes, though with a little axe,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hew down and fell the hardest-timberd oak.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By many hands your father was subdued;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But only slaughterd by the ireful arm

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Who crownd the gracious duke in high despite,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Laughd in his face; and when with grief he wept,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A napkin steeped in the harmless blood

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And after many scorns, many foul taunts,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They took his head, and on the gates of York

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They set the same; and there it doth remain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The saddest spectacle that eer I viewd.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Clifford, boisterous Clifford! thou hast slain

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: The flower of Europe for his chivalry;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And treacherously hast thou vanquishd him,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For hand to hand he would have vanquishd thee.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now my souls palace is become a prison:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Might in the ground be closed up in rest!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For never henceforth shall I joy again,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Never, O never shall I see more joy!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I cannot weep; for all my bodys moisture

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nor can my tongue unload my hearts great burthen;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For selfsame wind that I should speak withal

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Is kindling coals that fires all my breast,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And burns me up with flames that tears would quench.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: To weep is to make less the depth of grief:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Richard, I bear thy name; Ill venge thy death,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or die renowned by attempting it.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His name that valiant duke hath left with thee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His dukedom and his chair with me is left.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay, if thou be that princely eagles bird,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Show thy descent by gazing gainst the sun:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: March. Enter WARWICK, MONTAGUE, and their army

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, fair lords! What fare? what news abroad?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Our baleful news, and at each words deliverance

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The words would add more anguish than the wounds.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Warwick, Warwick! that Plantagenet,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Which held three dearly as his souls redemption,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ten days ago I drownd these news in tears;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now, to add more measure to your woes,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I come to tell you things sith then befalln.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were brought me of your loss and his depart.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I, then in London keeper of the king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Musterd my soldiers, gatherd flocks of friends,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And very well appointed, as I thought,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Marchd toward Saint Albans to intercept the queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Bearing the king in my behalf along;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For by my scouts I was advertised

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That she was coming with a full intent

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To dash our late decree in parliament

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Touching King Henrys oath and your succession.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Short tale to make, we at Saint Albans met

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Our battles joind, and both sides fiercely fought:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But whether twas the coldness of the king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Who lookd full gently on his warlike queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That robbd my soldiers of their heated spleen;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or whether twas report of her success;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or more than common fear of Cliffords rigour,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Who thunders to his captives blood and death,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I cannot judge: but to conclude with truth,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Their weapons like to lightning came and went;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Our soldiers, like the night-owls lazy flight,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or like an idle thresher with a flail,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I cheerd them up with justice of our cause,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With promise of high pay and great rewards:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But all in vain; they had no heart to fight,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And we in them no hope to win the day;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So that we fled; the king unto the queen;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Lord George your brother, Norfolk and myself,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In haste, post-haste, are come to join with you:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For in the marches here we heard you were,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Making another head to fight again.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And when came George from Burgundy to England?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And for your brother, he was lately sent

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With aid of soldiers to this needful war.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But neer till now his scandal of retire.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Can pluck the diadem from faint Henrys head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And wring the awful sceptre from his fist,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were he as famous and as bold in war

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As he is famed for mildness, peace, and prayer.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But in this troublous time whats to be done?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Shall we go throw away our coats of steel,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or shall we on the helmets of our foes

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If for the last, say ay, and to it, lords.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And therefore comes my brother Montague.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Attend me, lords. The proud insulting queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With Clifford and the haught Northumberland,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And of their feather many more proud birds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: He swore consent to your succession,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: His oath enrolled in the parliament;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now to London all the crew are gone,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To frustrate both his oath and what beside

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: May make against the house of Lancaster.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Will but amount to five and twenty thousand,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, Via! to London will we march amain,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And once again bestride our foaming steeds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And once again cry Charge upon our foes!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But never once again turn back and fly.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Neer may he live to see a sunshine day,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That cries Retire, if Warwick bid him stay.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And when thou failst--as God forbid the hour!--

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The next degree is Englands royal throne;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For King of England shalt thou be proclaimd

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In every borough as we pass along;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And he that throws not up his cap for joy

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But sound the trumpets, and about our task.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I come to pierce it, or to give thee mine.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Then strike up drums: God and Saint George for us!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now! what news?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The queen is coming with a puissant host;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And craves your company for speedy counsel.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why then it sorts, brave warriors, lets away.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE II. Before York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET,  PRINCE EDWARD, CLIFFORD, and NORTHUMBERLAND, with drum and trumpets

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yonders the head of that arch-enemy

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That sought to be encompassd with your crown:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To see this sight, it irks my very soul.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Withhold revenge, dear God! tis not my fault,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My gracious liege, this too much lenity

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And harmful pity must be laid aside.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not to the beast that would usurp their den.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not his that spoils her young before her face.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who scapes the lurking serpents mortal sting?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not he that sets his foot upon her back.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The smallest worm will turn being trodden on,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ambitious York doth level at thy crown,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He, but a duke, would have his son a king,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And raise his issue, like a loving sire;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Didst yield consent to disinherit him,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which argued thee a most unloving father.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Unreasonable creatures feed their young;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And though mans face be fearful to their eyes,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Yet, in protection of their tender ones,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who hath not seen them, even with those wings

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which sometime they have used with fearful flight,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Make war with him that climbd unto their nest,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Offer their own lives in their youngs defence?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For shame, my liege, make them your precedent!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Were it not pity that this goodly boy

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Should lose his birthright by his fathers fault,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And long hereafter say unto his child,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What my great-grandfather and his grandsire got

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My careless father fondly gave away?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And let his manly face, which promiseth

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Full well hath Clifford playd the orator,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Inferring arguments of mighty force.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That things ill-got had ever bad success?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And happy always was it for that son

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ill leave my son my virtuous deeds behind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And would my father had left me no more!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For all the rest is held at such a rate

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than in possession and jot of pleasure.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, cousin York! would thy best friends did know

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And this soft courage makes your followers faint.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: You promised knighthood to our forward son:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Unsheathe your sword, and dub him presently.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward, kneel down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And learn this lesson, draw thy sword in right.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: My gracious father, by your kingly leave,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Ill draw it as apparent to the crown,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And in that quarrel use it to the death.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Royal commanders, be in readiness:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For with a band of thirty thousand men

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Comes Warwick, backing of the Duke of York;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And in the towns, as they do march along,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Proclaims him king, and many fly to him:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Darraign your battle, for they are at hand.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I would your highness would depart the field:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The queen hath best success when you are absent.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, thats my fortune too; therefore Ill stay.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be it with resolution then to fight.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My royal father, cheer these noble lords

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And hearten those that fight in your defence:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry Saint George!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: March. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD, WARWICK, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, and Soldiers

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now, perjured Henry! wilt thou kneel for grace,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And set thy diadem upon my head;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Go, rate thy minions, proud insulting boy!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I am his king, and he should bow his knee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I was adopted heir by his consent:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Since when, his oath is broke; for, as I hear,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: You, that are king, though he do wear the crown,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Have caused him, by new act of parliament,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: To blot out me, and put his own son in.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And reason too:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who should succeed the father but the son?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or any he the proudest of thy sort.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Twas you that killd young Rutland, was it not?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For Gods sake, lords, give signal to the fight.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What sayst thou, Henry, wilt thou yield the crown?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick! dare you speak?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: When you and I met at Saint Albans last,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Your legs did better service than your hands.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then twas my turn to fly, and now tis thine.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The execution of my big-swoln heart

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I slew thy father, callst thou him a child?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But ere sunset Ill make thee curse the deed.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am a king, and privileged to speak.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: By him that made us all, I am resolved

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: that Cliffords manhood lies upon his tongue.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That neer shall dine unless thou yield the crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For York in justice puts his armour on.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: If that be right which Warwick says is right,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: There is no wrong, but every thing is right.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For, well I wot, thou hast thy mothers tongue.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Markd by the destinies to be avoided,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As venom toads, or lizards dreadful stings.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Iron of Naples hid with English gilt,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Whose father bears the title of a king,--

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As if a channel should be calld the sea,--

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Shamest thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: To let thy tongue detect thy base-born heart?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: To make this shameless callet know herself.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Although thy husband may be Menelaus;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And neer was Agamemnons brother wrongd

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: By that false woman, as this king by thee.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His father revelld in the heart of France,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And tamed the king, and made the dauphin stoop;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And had he matchd according to his state,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: He might have kept that glory to this day;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But when he took a beggar to his bed,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And graced thy poor sire with his bridal-day,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Even then that sunshine brewd a shower for him,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That washd his fathers fortunes forth of France,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And heapd sedition on his crown at home.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For what hath broachd this tumult but thy pride?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And we, in pity of the gentle king,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had slippd our claim until another age.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And that thy summer bred us no increase,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: We set the axe to thy usurping root;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And though the edge hath something hit ourselves,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Yet, know thou, since we have begun to strike,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Well never leave till we have hewn thee down,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And, in this resolution, I defy thee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Not willing any longer conference,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Since thou deniest the gentle king to speak.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sound trumpets! let our bloody colours wave!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And either victory, or else a grave.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stay, Edward.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No, wrangling woman, well no longer stay:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: SCENE III. A field of battle between Towton and Saxton, in

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Yorkshire.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Alarum. Excursions. Enter WARWICK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Forspent with toil, as runners with a race,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I lay me down a little while to breathe;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For strokes received, and many blows repaid,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Have robbd my strong-knit sinews of their strength,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter EDWARD, running

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Smile, gentle heaven! or strike, ungentle death!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For this world frowns, and Edwards sun is clouded.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, my lord! what hap? what hope of good?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter GEORGE

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us:

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Enter RICHARD

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thy brothers blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Broachd with the steely point of Cliffords lance;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And in the very pangs of death he cried,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Like to a dismal clangour heard from far,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Warwick, revenge! brother, revenge my death!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So, underneath the belly of their steeds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That staind their fetlocks in his smoking blood,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill kill my horse, because I will not fly.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why stand we like soft-hearted women here,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And look upon, as if the tragedy

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were playd in jest by counterfeiting actors?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Here on my knee I vow to God above,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill never pause again, never stand still,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or fortune given me measure of revenge.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And in this vow do chain my soul to thine!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And, ere my knee rise from the earths cold face,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Thou setter up and plucker down of kings,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Beseeching thee, if with they will it stands

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That to my foes this body must be prey,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Yet that thy brazen gates of heaven may ope,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And give sweet passage to my sinful soul!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now, lords, take leave until we meet again,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whereer it be, in heaven or in earth.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Brother, give me thy hand; and, gentle Warwick,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Let me embrace thee in my weary arms:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I, that did never weep, now melt with woe

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That winter should cut off our spring-time so.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords farewell.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Yet let us all together to our troops,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And give them leave to fly that will not stay;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And call them pillars that will stand to us;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: As victors wear at the Olympian games:

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: For yet is hope of life and victory.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Forslow no longer, make we hence amain.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the field.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Excursions. Enter RICHARD and CLIFFORD

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Wert thou environd with a brazen wall.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: This is the hand that stabbd thy father York;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And heres the heart that triumphs in their death

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To execute the like upon thyself;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And so, have at thee!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: They fight. WARWICK comes; CLIFFORD flies

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay Warwick, single out some other chase;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Alarum. Enter KING HENRY VI alone

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: This battle fares like to the mornings war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When dying clouds contend with growing light,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can neither call it perfect day nor night.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Forced to retire by fury of the wind:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now one the better, then another best;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Yet neither conqueror nor conquered:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So is the equal of this fell war.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here on this molehill will I sit me down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To whom God will, there be the victory!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have chid me from the battle; swearing both

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: They prosper best of all when I am thence.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Would I were dead! if Gods good will were so;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For what is in this world but grief and woe?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O God! methinks it were a happy life,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be no better than a homely swain;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To sit upon a hill, as I do now,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thereby to see the minutes how they run,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many make the hour full complete;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many hours bring about the day;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many days will finish up the year;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many years a mortal man may live.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When this is known, then to divide the times:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I tend my flock;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I take my rest;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I contemplate;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I sport myself;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many days my ewes have been with young;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So minutes, hours, days, months, and years,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Passd over to the end they were created,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To shepherds looking on their silly sheep,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than doth a rich embroiderd canopy

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To kings that fear their subjects treachery?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, yes, it doth; a thousand-fold it doth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And to conclude, the shepherds homely curds,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His wonted sleep under a fresh trees shade,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: All which secure and sweetly he enjoys,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is far beyond a princes delicates,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His viands sparkling in a golden cup,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His body couched in a curious bed,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Alarum. Enter a Son that has killed his father, dragging in the dead body

speaker: Son
text_entry: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.

speaker: Son
text_entry: This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight,

speaker: Son
text_entry: May be possessed with some store of crowns;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And I, that haply take them from him now,

speaker: Son
text_entry: May yet ere night yield both my life and them

speaker: Son
text_entry: To some man else, as this dead man doth me.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Whos this? O God! it is my fathers face,

speaker: Son
text_entry: Whom in this conflict I unwares have killd.

speaker: Son
text_entry: O heavy times, begetting such events!

speaker: Son
text_entry: From London by the king was I pressd forth;

speaker: Son
text_entry: My father, being the Earl of Warwicks man,

speaker: Son
text_entry: Came on the part of York, pressd by his master;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And I, who at his hands received my life, him

speaker: Son
text_entry: Have by my hands of life bereaved him.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!

speaker: Son
text_entry: And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!

speaker: Son
text_entry: My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And no more words till they have flowd their fill.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Weep, wretched man, Ill aid thee tear for tear;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be blind with tears, and break oercharged with grief.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter a Father that has killed his son, bringing in the body

speaker: Father
text_entry: Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold:

speaker: Father
text_entry: For I have bought it with an hundred blows.

speaker: Father
text_entry: But let me see: is this our foemans face?

speaker: Father
text_entry: Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!

speaker: Father
text_entry: Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Throw up thine eye! see, see what showers arise,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Blown with the windy tempest of my heart,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Upon thy words, that kill mine eye and heart!

speaker: Father
text_entry: O, pity, God, this miserable age!

speaker: Father
text_entry: What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural,

speaker: Father
text_entry: This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!

speaker: Father
text_entry: O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon,

speaker: Father
text_entry: And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Woe above woe! grief more than common grief!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The red rose and the white are on his face,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The fatal colours of our striving houses:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The one his purple blood right well resembles;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wither one rose, and let the other flourish;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.

speaker: Son
text_entry: How will my mother for a fathers death

speaker: Son
text_entry: Take on with me and neer be satisfied!

speaker: Father
text_entry: How will my wife for slaughter of my son

speaker: Father
text_entry: Shed seas of tears and neer be satisfied!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How will the country for these woful chances

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Misthink the king and not be satisfied!

speaker: Son
text_entry: Was ever son so rued a fathers death?

speaker: Father
text_entry: Was ever father so bemoand his son?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Was ever king so grieved for subjects woe?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Ill bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Exit with the body

speaker: Father
text_entry: These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet;

speaker: Father
text_entry: My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre,

speaker: Father
text_entry: For from my heart thine image neer shall go;

speaker: Father
text_entry: My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;

speaker: Father
text_entry: And so obsequious will thy father be,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Even for the loss of thee, having no more,

speaker: Father
text_entry: As Priam was for all his valiant sons.

speaker: Father
text_entry: Ill bear thee hence; and let them fight that will,

speaker: Father
text_entry: For I have murdered where I should not kill.

speaker: Father
text_entry: Exit with the body

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here sits a king more woful than you are.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Alarums: excursions. Enter QUEEN MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, and EXETER

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Fly, father, fly! for all your friends are fled,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And Warwick rages like a chafed bull:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Having the fearful flying hare in sight,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And bloody steel graspd in their ireful hands,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Are at our backs; and therefore hence amain.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Away! for vengeance comes along with them:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or else come after: Ill away before.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not that I fear to stay, but love to go

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whither the queen intends. Forward; away!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE VI. Another part of the field.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A loud alarum. Enter CLIFFORD, wounded

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: More than my bodys parting with my soul!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My love and fear glued many friends to thee;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Impairing Henry, strengthening misproud York,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The common people swarm like summer flies;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And who shines now but Henrys enemies?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thy burning car never had scorchd the earth!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, Henry, hadst thou swayd as kings should do,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or as thy father and his father did,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Giving no ground unto the house of York,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: They never then had sprung like summer flies;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I and ten thousand in this luckless realm

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Had left no mourning widows for our death;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The foe is merciless, and will not pity;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For at their hands I have deserved no pity.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The air hath got into my deadly wounds,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I stabbd your fathers bosoms, split my breast.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He faints

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Alarum and retreat. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD, MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and Soldiers

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now breathe we, lords: good fortune bids us pause,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That led calm Henry, though he were a king,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: As doth a sail, filld with a fretting gust,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Command an argosy to stem the waves.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: No, tis impossible he should escape,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For, though before his face I speak the words

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Your brother Richard markd him for the grave:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And wheresoeer he is, hes surely dead.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: CLIFFORD groans, and dies

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: A deadly groan, like life and deaths departing.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: See who it is: and, now the battles ended,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: If friend or foe, let him be gently used.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Revoke that doom of mercy, for tis Clifford;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who not contented that he loppd the branch

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But set his murdering knife unto the root

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I mean our princely father, Duke of York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From off the gates of York fetch down the head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Your fathers head, which Clifford placed there;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Instead whereof let this supply the room:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Measure for measure must be answered.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That nothing sung but death to us and ours:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I think his understanding is bereft.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dark cloudy death oershades his beams of life,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: O, would he did! and so perhaps he doth:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tis but his policy to counterfeit,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Because he would avoid such bitter taunts

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Which in the time of death he gave our father.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: If so thou thinkst, vex him with eager words.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Thou pitiedst Rutland; I will pity thee.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Wheres Captain Margaret, to fence you now?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: They mock thee, Clifford: swear as thou wast wont.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: What, not an oath? nay, then the world goes hard

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I know by that hes dead; and, by my soul,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If this right hand would buy two hours life,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That I in all despite might rail at him,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: This hand should chop it off, and with the

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: issuing blood

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Stifle the villain whose unstanched thirst

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: York and young Rutland could not satisfy.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, but hes dead: off with the traitors head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And rear it in the place your fathers stands.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now to London with triumphant march,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: There to be crowned Englands royal king:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So shalt thou sinew both these lands together;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The scatterd foe that hopes to rise again;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: First will I see the coronation;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And then to Brittany Ill cross the sea,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For in thy shoulder do I build my seat,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And never will I undertake the thing

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And George, of Clarence: Warwick, as ourself,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For Gloucesters dukedom is too ominous.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tut, thats a foolish observation:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To see these honours in possession.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE I. A forest in the north of England.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter two Keepers, with cross-bows in their hands

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Under this thick-grown brake well shroud ourselves;

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: For through this laund anon the deer will come;

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: And in this covert will we make our stand,

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Culling the principal of all the deer.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Ill stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Here stand we both, and aim we at the best:

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: And, for the time shall not seem tedious,

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Ill tell thee what befell me on a day

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: In this self-place where now we mean to stand.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Here comes a man; lets stay till he be past.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI, disguised, with a prayerbook

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From Scotland am I stoln, even of pure love,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No, Harry, Harry, tis no land of thine;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy place is filld, thy sceptre wrung from thee,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy balm washd off wherewith thou wast anointed:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No humble suitors press to speak for right,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No, not a man comes for redress of thee;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For how can I help them, and not myself?

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Ay, heres a deer whose skins a keepers fee:

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: This is the quondam king; lets seize upon him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me embrace thee, sour adversity,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For wise men say it is the wisest course.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Forbear awhile; well hear a little more.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My queen and son are gone to France for aid;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is thither gone, to crave the French kings sister

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To wife for Edward: if this news be true,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor queen and son, your labour is but lost;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Warwick is a subtle orator,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: By this account then Margaret may win him;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For shes a woman to be pitied much:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Her sighs will make a battery in his breast;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Her tears will pierce into a marble heart;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And Nero will be tainted with remorse,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, but shes come to beg, Warwick to give;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He smiles, and says his Edward is installd;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whiles Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Inferreth arguments of mighty strength,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And in conclusion wins the king from her,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: With promise of his sister, and what else,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To strengthen and support King Edwards place.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O Margaret, thus twill be; and thou, poor soul,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Art then forsaken, as thou wentst forlorn!

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Say, what art thou that talkst of kings and queens?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: More than I seem, and less than I was born to:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A man at least, for less I should not be;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And men may talk of kings, and why not I?

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Ay, but thou talkst as if thou wert a king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, so I am, in mind; and thats enough.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: But, if thou be a king, where is thy crown?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My crown is in my heart, not on my head;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not decked with diamonds and Indian stones,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor to be seen: my crown is called content:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Well, if you be a king crownd with content,

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Your crown content and you must be contented

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: To go along with us; for as we think,

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: You are the king King Edward hath deposed;

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Will apprehend you as his enemy.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But did you never swear, and break an oath?

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: No, never such an oath; nor will not now.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Here in this country, where we now remain.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I was anointed king at nine months old;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My father and my grandfather were kings,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And you were sworn true subjects unto me:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And tell me, then, have you not broke your oaths?

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: No;

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: For we were subjects but while you were king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, am I dead? do I not breathe a man?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Look, as I blow this feather from my face,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And as the air blows it to me again,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Obeying with my wind when I do blow,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And yielding to another when it blows,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Commanded always by the greater gust;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Such is the lightness of you common men.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But do not break your oaths; for of that sin

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go where you will, the king shall be commanded;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And be you kings, command, and Ill obey.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: We are true subjects to the king, King Edward.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So would you be again to Henry,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If he were seated as King Edward is.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: We charge you, in Gods name, and the kings,

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: To go with us unto the officers.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In Gods name, lead; your kings name be obeyd:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And what God will, that let your king perform;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And what he will, I humbly yield unto.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE II. London. The palace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and LADY GREY

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Albans field

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: This ladys husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: His lands then seized on by the conqueror:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her suit is now to repossess those lands;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Which we in justice cannot well deny,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Because in quarrel of the house of York

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your highness shall do well to grant her suit;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It were dishonour to deny it her.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: It were no less; but yet Ill make a pause.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Yea, is it so?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I see the lady hath a thing to grant,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Before the king will grant her humble suit.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He knows the game: how true

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: he keeps the wind!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Silence!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Widow, we will consider of your suit;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And come some other time to know our mind.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: May it please your highness to resolve me now;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, widow? then Ill warrant

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: you all your lands,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: An if what pleases him shall pleasure you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Fight closer, or, good faith, youll catch a blow.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I fear her not, unless she

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: chance to fall.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that! for hell

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: take vantages.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: How many children hast thou, widow? tell me.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I think he means to beg a

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: child of her.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Nay, whip me then: hell rather

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: give her two.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Three, my most gracious lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  You shall have four, if youll

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: be ruled by him.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Twere pity they should lose their fathers lands.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Lords, give us leave: Ill try this widows wit.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, good leave have you; for

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: you will have leave,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE retire

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And would you not do much to do them good?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: To do them good, I would sustain some harm.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Then get your husbands lands, to do them good.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Therefore I came unto your majesty.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ill tell you how these lands are to be got.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: So shall you bind me to your highness service.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: What you command, that rests in me to do.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then I will do what your grace commands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  He plies her hard; and much rain

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: wears the marble.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  As red as fire! nay, then

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: her wax must melt.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: An easy task; tis but to love a king.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Thats soon performd, because I am a subject.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, then, thy husbands lands I freely give thee.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The match is made; she seals it

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: with a curtsy.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But stay thee, tis the fruits of love I mean.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What love, thinkst thou, I sue so much to get?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: My mind will never grant what I perceive

speaker: LADY GREY
