text_entry: Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husbands lands.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: For by that loss I will not purchase them.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Therein thou wrongst thy children mightily.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: But, mighty lord, this merry inclination

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Accords not with the sadness of my suit:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Please you dismiss me either with ay or no.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, if thou wilt say ay to my request;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No if thou dost say no to my demand.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The widow likes him not, she

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: knits her brows.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He is the bluntest wooer in

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Christendom.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: [Aside]  Her looks do argue her replete with modesty;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her words do show her wit incomparable;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: All her perfections challenge sovereignty:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: One way or other, she is for a king;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And she shall be my love, or else my queen.--

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Tis better said than done, my gracious lord:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I am a subject fit to jest withal,

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: But far unfit to be a sovereign.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I speak no more than what my soul intends;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And that is more than I will yield unto:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I know I am too mean to be your queen,

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And yet too good to be your concubine.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No more than when my daughters call thee mother.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, by Gods mother, I, being but a bachelor,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have other some: why, tis a happy thing

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To be the father unto many sons.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The ghostly father now hath done

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: his shrift.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  When he was made a shriver,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: twas for shift.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Youll think it strange if I should marry her.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To whom, my lord?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, Clarence, to myself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That would be ten days wonder at the least.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Thats a day longer than a wonder lasts.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her suit is granted for her husbands lands.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter a Nobleman

speaker: Nobleman
text_entry: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken,

speaker: Nobleman
text_entry: And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: See that he be conveyd unto the Tower:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To question of his apprehension.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ay, Edward will use women honourably.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To cross me from the golden time I look for!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet, between my souls desire and me--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The lustful Edwards title buried--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And all the unlookd for issue of their bodies,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A cold premeditation for my purpose!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Like one that stands upon a promontory,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And spies a far-off shore where he would tread,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Wishing his foot were equal with his eye,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And chides the sea that sunders him from thence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Saying, hell lade it dry to have his way:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So do I wish the crown, being so far off;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And so I say, Ill cut the causes off,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Flattering me with impossibilities.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My eyes too quick, my heart oerweens too much,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unless my hand and strength could equal them.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What other pleasure can the world afford?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill make my heaven in a ladys lap,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And deck my body in gay ornaments,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O miserable thought! and more unlikely

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, love forswore me in my  mothers womb:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, for I should not deal in her soft laws,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To shrink mine arm up like a witherd shrub;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To make an envious mountain on my back,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where sits deformity to mock my body;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To shape my legs of an unequal size;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To disproportion me in every part,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Like to a chaos, or an unlickd bear-whelp

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That carries no impression like the dam.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And am I then a man to be beloved?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then, since this earth affords no joy to me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But to command, to cheque, to oerbear such

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As are of better person than myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill make my heaven to dream upon the crown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Until my mis-shaped trunk that bears this head

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be round impaled with a glorious crown.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet I know not how to get the crown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For many lives stand between me and home:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Seeking a way and straying from the way;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Not knowing how to find the open air,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But toiling desperately to find it out,--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Torment myself to catch the English crown:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And from that torment I will free myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And cry Content to that which grieves my heart,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And wet my cheeks with artificial tears,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And frame my face to all occasions.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill slay more gazers than the basilisk;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill play the orator as well as Nestor,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I can add colours to the chameleon,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Change shapes with Proteus for advantages,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And set the murderous Machiavel to school.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tut, were it farther off, Ill pluck it down.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE III. France. KING LEWIS XIs palace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING LEWIS XI, his sister BONA,  his Admiral, called BOURBON, PRINCE EDWARD, QUEEN  MARGARET, and OXFORD. KING LEWIS XI sits, and riseth up again

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: No, mighty King of France: now Margaret

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Where kings command. I was, I must confess,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Great Albions queen in former golden days:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But now mischance hath trod my title down,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And with dishonour laid me on the ground;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Where I must take like seat unto my fortune,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And to my humble seat conform myself.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And stops my tongue, while heart is drownd in cares.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Whateer it be, be thou still like thyself,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And sit thee by our side:

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Seats her by him

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Yield not thy neck

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: To fortunes yoke, but let thy dauntless mind

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Still ride in triumph over all mischance.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: It shall be eased, if France can yield relief.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That Henry, sole possessor of my love,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Is of a king become a banishd man,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Usurps the regal title and the seat

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Of Englands true-anointed lawful king.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: This is the cause that I, poor Margaret,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With this my son, Prince Edward, Henrys heir,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And if thou fail us, all our hope is done:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our people and our peers are both misled,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: While we bethink a means to break it off.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: The more I stay, the more Ill succor thee.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Enter WARWICK

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Whats he approacheth boldly to our presence?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our Earl of Warwick, Edwards greatest friend.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France?

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: He descends. She ariseth

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I come, in kindness and unfeigned love,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: First, to do greetings to thy royal person;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And then to crave a league of amity;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And lastly, to confirm that amity

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To Englands king in lawful marriage.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: [Aside]  If that go forward, Henrys hope is done.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: [To BONA]  And, gracious madam, in our kings behalf,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I am commanded, with your leave and favour,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Humbly to kiss your hand, and with my tongue

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To tell the passion of my sovereigns heart;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where fame, late entering at his heedful ears,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath placed thy beautys image and thy virtue.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before you answer Warwick. His demand

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Springs not from Edwards well-meant honest love,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But from deceit bred by necessity;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For how can tyrants safely govern home,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Unless abroad they purchase great alliance?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That Henry liveth still: but were he dead,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henrys son.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Look, therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For though usurpers sway the rule awhile,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Injurious Margaret!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And why not queen?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Because thy father Henry did usurp;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And thou no more are prince than she is queen.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain;

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Who by his prowess conquered all France:

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: From these our Henry lineally descends.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: All that which Henry Fifth had gotten?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But for the rest, you tell a pedigree

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of threescore and two years; a silly time

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To make prescription for a kingdoms worth.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Whom thou obeyedst thirty and six years,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Call him my king by whose injurious doom

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Was done to death? and more than so, my father,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Even in the downfall of his mellowd years,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: When nature brought him to the door of death?

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And I the house of York.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: While I use further conference with Warwick.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: They stand aloof

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Heavens grant that Warwicks words bewitch him not!

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Now Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Is Edward your true king? for I were loath

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: But is he gracious in the peoples eye?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Then further, all dissembling set aside,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Tell me for truth the measure of his love

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Unto our sister Bona.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Such it seems

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As may beseem a monarch like himself.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Myself have often heard him say and swear

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That this his love was an eternal plant,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Whereof the root was fixd in virtues ground,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The leaves and fruit maintaind with beautys sun,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine:

speaker: BONA
text_entry: To WARWICK

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Yet I confess that often ere this day,

speaker: BONA
text_entry: When I have heard your kings desert recounted,

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edwards;

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And now forthwith shall articles be drawn

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Touching the jointure that your king must make,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: To Edward, but not to the English king.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: By this alliance to make void my suit:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before thy coming Lewis was Henrys friend.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And still is friend to him and Margaret:

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: But if your title to the crown be weak,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: As may appear by Edwards good success,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Then tis but reason that I be released

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: From giving aid which late I promised.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: That your estate requires and mine can yield.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And as for you yourself, our quondam queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You have a father able to maintain you;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And better twere you troubled him than France.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Proud setter up and puller down of kings!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy sly conveyance and thy lords false love;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Post blows a horn within

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Enter a Post

speaker: Post
text_entry: [To WARWICK]  My lord ambassador, these letters are for you,

speaker: Post
text_entry: Sent from your brother, Marquess Montague:

speaker: Post
text_entry: To KING LEWIS XI

speaker: Post
text_entry: These from our king unto your majesty:

speaker: Post
text_entry: To QUEEN MARGARET

speaker: Post
text_entry: And, madam, these for you; from whom I know not.

speaker: Post
text_entry: They all read their letters

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: I like it well that our fair queen and mistress

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps, as he were nettled:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I hope alls for the best.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Mine, full of sorrow and hearts discontent.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: What! has your king married the Lady Grey!

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And now, to soothe your forgery and his,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Sends me a paper to persuade me patience?

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I told your majesty as much before:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: This proveth Edwards love and Warwicks honesty.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: King Lewis, I here protest, in sight of heaven,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That I am clear from this misdeed of Edwards,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: No more my king, for he dishonours me,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But most himself, if he could see his shame.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Did I forget that by the house of York

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My father came untimely to his death?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Did I impale him with the regal crown?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Did I put Henry from his native right?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And am I guerdond at the last with shame?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shame on himself! for my desert is honour:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And to repair my honour lost for him,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I here renounce him and return to Henry.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My noble queen, let former grudges pass,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And henceforth I am thy true servitor:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And replant Henry in his former state.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Warwick, these words have turnd my hate to love;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And I forgive and quite forget old faults,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And joy that thou becomest King Henrys friend.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That, if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With some few bands of chosen soldiers,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill undertake to land them on our coast

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And force the tyrant from his seat by war.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hes very likely now to fall from him,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For matching more for wanton lust than honour,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or than for strength and safety of our country.

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged

speaker: BONA
text_entry: But by thy help to this distressed queen?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

speaker: BONA
text_entry: My quarrel and this English queens are one.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margarets.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Therefore at last I firmly am resolved

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: You shall have aid.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Then, Englands messenger, return in post,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And tell false Edward, thy supposed king,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: That Lewis of France is sending over masquers

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: To revel it with him and his new bride:

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Thou seest whats past, go fear thy king withal.

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Tell him, in hope hell prove a widower shortly,

speaker: BONA
text_entry: Ill wear the willow garland for his sake.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And I am ready to put armour on.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And therefore Ill uncrown him eret be long.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Theres thy reward: be gone.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exit Post

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: But, Warwick,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle;

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And, as occasion serves, this noble queen

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This shall assure my constant loyalty,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That if our queen and this young prince agree,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill join mine eldest daughter and my joy

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And, with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That only Warwicks daughter shall be thine.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: He gives his hand to WARWICK

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Shalt waft them over with our royal fleet.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: I long till Edward fall by wars mischance,

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: For mocking marriage with a dame of France.

speaker: KING LEWIS XI
text_entry: Exeunt all but WARWICK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I came from Edward as ambassador,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But I return his sworn and mortal foe:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But dreadful war shall answer his demand.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Had he none else to make a stale but me?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I was the chief that raised him to the crown,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And Ill be chief to bring him down again:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Not that I pity Henrys misery,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But seek revenge on Edwards mockery.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The palace.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, SOMERSET, and MONTAGUE

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Alas, you know, tis far from hence to France;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: How could he stay till Warwick made return?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And his well-chosen bride.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, attended; QUEEN ELIZABETH, PEMBROKE, STAFFORD, HASTINGS, and others

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which are so weak of courage and in judgment

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That theyll take no offence at our abuse.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Suppose they take offence without a cause,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: They are but Lewis and Warwick: I am Edward,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Your king and Warwicks, and must have my will.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And shall have your will, because our king:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Not I:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, God forbid that I should wish them severd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom God hath joind together; ay, and twere pity

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To sunder them that yoke so well together.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Should not become my wife and Englands queen.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And you too, Somerset and Montague,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Speak freely what you think.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Becomes your enemy, for mocking him

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: About the marriage of the Lady Bona.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: By such invention as I can devise?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Yet, to have joind with France in such alliance

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Would more have strengthend this our commonwealth

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Why, knows not Montague that of itself

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: England is safe, if true within itself?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But the safer when tis backd with France.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Tis better using France than trusting France:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Let us be backd with God and with the seas

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Which He hath given for fence impregnable,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And with their helps only defend ourselves;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: In them and in ourselves our safety lies.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, what of that? it was my will and grant;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And for this once my will shall stand for law.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet methinks your grace hath not done well,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unto the brother of your loving bride;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She better would have fitted me or Clarence:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Or else you would not have bestowd the heir

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Of the Lord Bonville on your new wifes son,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Alas, poor Clarence! is it for a wife

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: In choosing for yourself, you showd your judgment,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which being shallow, you give me leave

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To play the broker in mine own behalf;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And not be tied unto his brothers will.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: My lords, before it pleased his majesty

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To raise my state to title of a queen,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Do me but right, and you must all confess

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That I was not ignoble of descent;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And meaner than myself have had like fortune.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: But as this title honours me and mine,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: So your dislike, to whom I would be pleasing,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What danger or what sorrow can befall thee,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: So long as Edward is thy constant friend,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Unless they seek for hatred at my hands;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  I hear, yet say not much, but think the more.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter a Post

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, messenger, what letters or what news

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: From France?

speaker: Post
text_entry: My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words,

speaker: Post
text_entry: But such as I, without your special pardon,

speaker: Post
text_entry: Dare not relate.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

speaker: Post
text_entry: At my depart, these were his very words:

speaker: Post
text_entry: Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king,

speaker: Post
text_entry: That Lewis of France is sending over masquers

speaker: Post
text_entry: To revel it with him and his new bride.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

speaker: Post
text_entry: These were her words, utterd with mad disdain:

speaker: Post
text_entry: Tell him, in hope hell prove a widower shortly,

speaker: Post
text_entry: Ill wear the willow garland for his sake.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I blame not her, she could say little less;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: She had the wrong. But what said Henrys queen?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For I have heard that she was there in place.

speaker: Post
text_entry: Tell him, quoth she, my mourning weeds are done,

speaker: Post
text_entry: And I am ready to put armour on.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Belike she minds to play the Amazon.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But what said Warwick to these injuries?

speaker: Post
text_entry: He, more incensed against your majesty

speaker: Post
text_entry: Than all the rest, discharged me with these words:

speaker: Post
text_entry: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,

speaker: Post
text_entry: And therefore Ill uncrown him eret be long.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well I will arm me, being thus forewarnd:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: They shall have wars and pay for their presumption.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

speaker: Post
text_entry: Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so linkd in

speaker: Post
text_entry: friendship

speaker: Post
text_entry: That young Prince Edward marries Warwicks daughter.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For I will hence to Warwicks other daughter;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I may not prove inferior to yourself.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: You that love me and Warwick, follow me.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Exit CLARENCE, and SOMERSET follows

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Not I:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My thoughts aim at a further matter; I

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stay not for the love of Edward, but the crown.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet am I armd against the worst can happen;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And haste is needful in this desperate case.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Go levy men, and make prepare for war;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: They are already, or quickly will be landed:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Myself in person will straight follow you.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt PEMBROKE and STAFFORD

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: If it be so, then both depart to him;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I rather wish you foes than hollow friends:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But if you mind to hold your true obedience,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Give me assurance with some friendly vow,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That I may never have you in suspect.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: So God help Montague as he proves true!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And Hastings as he favours Edwards cause!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, so! then am I sure of victory.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE II. A plain in Warwickshire.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter WARWICK and OXFORD, with French soldiers

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The common people by numbers swarm to us.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter CLARENCE and SOMERSET

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But see where Somerset and Clarence come!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Fear not that, my lord.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To rest mistrustful where a noble heart

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath pawnd an open hand in sign of love;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Else might I think that Clarence, Edwards brother,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now what rests but, in nights coverture,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thy brother being carelessly encampd,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: His soldiers lurking in the towns about,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And but attended by a simple guard,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: We may surprise and take him at our pleasure?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Our scouts have found the adventure very easy:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That as Ulysses and stout Diomede

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus tents,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So we, well coverd with the nights black mantle,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: At unawares may beat down Edwards guard

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And seize himself; I say not, slaughter him,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For I intend but only to surprise him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You that will follow me to this attempt,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: They all cry, Henry!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, then, lets on our way in silent sort:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE III. Edwards camp, near Warwick.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter three Watchmen, to guard KING EDWARD IVs tent

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand:

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: The king by this is set him down to sleep.

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: What, will he not to bed?

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Never to lie and take his natural rest

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Till Warwick or himself be quite suppressd.

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: To-morrow then belike shall be the day,

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: If Warwick be so near as men report.

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: That with the king here resteth in his tent?

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Tis the Lord Hastings, the kings chiefest friend.

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: O, is it so? But why commands the king

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: That his chief followers lodge in towns about him,

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: While he himself keeps in the cold field?

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: Ay, but give me worship and quietness;

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: I like it better than a dangerous honour.

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: If Warwick knew in what estate he stands,

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent,

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: But to defend his person from night-foes?

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Enter WARWICK, CLARENCE, OXFORD, SOMERSET, and French soldiers, silent all

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Courage, my masters! honour now or never!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Who goes there?

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Stay, or thou diest!

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: WARWICK and the rest cry all, Warwick! Warwick!  and set upon the Guard, who fly, crying, Arm! arm! WARWICK and the rest following them

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: The drum playing and trumpet sounding, reenter  WARWICK, SOMERSET, and the rest, bringing KING  EDWARD IV out in his gown, sitting in a chair. RICHARD and HASTINGS fly over the stage

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: What are they that fly there?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thou calldst me king.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, but the case is alterd:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: When you disgraced me in my embassade,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then I degraded you from being king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And come now to create you Duke of York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Alas! how should you govern any kingdom,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That know not how to use ambassadors,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor how to be contented with one wife,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor how to study for the peoples welfare,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Of thee thyself and all thy complices,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Edward will always bear himself as king:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Though fortunes malice overthrow my state,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then, for his mind, be Edward Englands king:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Takes off his crown

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But Henry now shall wear the English crown,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My Lord of Somerset, at my request,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: See that forthwith Duke Edward be conveyd

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill follow you, and tell what answer

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: They lead him out forcibly

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What fates impose, that men must needs abide;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: It boots not to resist both wind and tide.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exit, guarded

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: What now remains, my lords, for us to do

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: But march to London with our soldiers?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, thats the first thing that we have to do;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To free King Henry from imprisonment

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And see him seated in the regal throne.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The palace.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and RIVERS

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: What late misfortune is befalln King Edward?

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: What! loss of some pitchd battle against Warwick?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Then is my sovereign slain?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Either betrayd by falsehood of his guard

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Or by his foe surprised at unawares:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And, as I further have to understand,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Is new committed to the Bishop of York,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Fell Warwicks brother and by that our foe.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: These news I must confess are full of grief;

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Till then fair hope must hinder lifes decay.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And I the rather wean me from despair

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For love of Edwards offspring in my womb:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: This is it that makes me bridle passion

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And bear with mildness my misfortunes cross;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: King Edwards fruit, true heir to the English crown.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I am informd that he comes towards London,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To set the crown once more on Henrys head:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Guess thou the rest; King Edwards friends must down,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: But, to prevent the tyrants violence,--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For trust not him that hath once broken faith,--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ill hence forthwith unto the sanctuary,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To save at least the heir of Edwards right:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If Warwick take us we are sure to die.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: SCENE V. A park near Middleham Castle In Yorkshire.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and STANLEY

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Into this chiefest thicket of the park.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He hath good usage and great liberty,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, often but attended with weak guard,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Comes hunting this way to disport himself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have advertised him by secret means

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That if about this hour he make his way

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Under the colour of his usual game,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He shall here find his friends with horse and men

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To set him free from his captivity.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter KING EDWARD IV and a Huntsman with him

speaker: Huntsman
text_entry: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Stand you thus close, to steal the bishops deer?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brother, the time and case requireth haste:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But whither shall we then?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To Lynn, my lord,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And ship from thence to Flanders.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well guessd, believe me; for that was my meaning.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But wherefore stay we? tis no time to talk.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Huntsman, what sayst thou? wilt thou go along?

speaker: Huntsman
text_entry: Better do so than tarry and be hangd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come then, away; lets ha no more ado.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwicks frown;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And pray that I may repossess the crown.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE VI. London. The Tower.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, CLARENCE, WARWICK,  SOMERSET, HENRY OF RICHMOND, OXFORD, MONTAGUE, and Lieutenant of the Tower

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Master lieutenant, now that God and friends

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have shaken Edward from the regal seat,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And turnd my captive state to liberty,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: At our enlargement what are thy due fees?

speaker: Lieutenant
text_entry: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns;

speaker: Lieutenant
text_entry: But if an humble prayer may prevail,

speaker: Lieutenant
text_entry: I then crave pardon of your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For what, lieutenant? for well using me?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nay, be thou sure Ill well requite thy kindness,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Conceive when after many moody thoughts

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: At last by notes of household harmony

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: They quite forget their loss of liberty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But, Warwick, after God, thou setst me free,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He was the author, thou the instrument.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore, that I may conquer fortunes spite

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: By living low, where fortune cannot hurt me,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And that the people of this blessed land

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: May not be punishd with my thwarting stars,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I here resign my government to thee,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now may seem as wise as virtuous,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: By spying and avoiding fortunes malice,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For few men rightly temper with the stars:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To whom the heavens in thy nativity

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As likely to be blest in peace and war;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And I choose Clarence only for protector.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That no dissension hinder government:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I make you both protectors of this land,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: While I myself will lead a private life

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And in devotion spend my latter days,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To sins rebuke and my Creators praise.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What answers Clarence to his sovereigns will?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That he consents, if Warwick yield consent;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For on thy fortune I repose myself.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Well yoke together, like a double shadow

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To Henrys body, and supply his place;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I mean, in bearing weight of government,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: While he enjoys the honour and his ease.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And all his lands and goods be confiscate.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What else? and that succession be determined.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But, with the first of all your chief affairs,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me entreat, for I command no more,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That Margaret your queen and my son Edward

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be sent for, to return from France with speed;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come hither, Englands hope.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lays his hand on his head

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If secret powers

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: This pretty lad will prove our countrys bliss.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His looks are full of peaceful majesty,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His head by nature framed to wear a crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Likely in time to bless a regal throne.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Make much of him, my lords, for this is he

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Must help you more than you are hurt by me.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter a Post

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What news, my friend?

speaker: Post
text_entry: That Edward is escaped from your brother,

speaker: Post
text_entry: And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unsavoury news! but how made he escape?

speaker: Post
text_entry: He was conveyd by Richard Duke of Gloucester

speaker: Post
text_entry: And the Lord Hastings, who attended him

speaker: Post
text_entry: In secret ambush on the forest side

speaker: Post
text_entry: And from the bishops huntsmen rescued him;

speaker: Post
text_entry: For hunting was his daily exercise.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My brother was too careless of his charge.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A salve for any sore that may betide.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt all but SOMERSET, HENRY OF RICHMOND, and OXFORD

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My lord, I like not of this flight of Edwards;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And we shall have more wars before t be long.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: As Henrys late presaging prophecy

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: What may befall him, to his harm and ours:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Forthwith well send him hence to Brittany,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Till storms be past of civil enmity.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: It shall be so; he shall to Brittany.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Come, therefore, lets about it speedily.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: SCENE VII. Before York.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and Soldiers

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And says that once more I shall interchange

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: My waned state for Henrys regal crown.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well have we passd and now repassd the seas

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And brought desired help from Burgundy:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What then remains, we being thus arrived

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But that we enter, as into our dukedom?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For many men that stumble at the threshold

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: By fair or foul means we must enter in,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For hither will our friends repair to us.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: My liege, Ill knock once more to summon them.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter, on the walls, the Mayor of York, and his Brethren

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And shut the gates for safety of ourselves;

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But, master mayor, if Henry be your king,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: As being well content with that alone.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  But when the fox hath once got in his nose,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hell soon find means to make the body follow.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Open the gates; we are King Henrys friends.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be opend.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: They descend

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The good old man would fain that all were well,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: So twere not long of him; but being enterd,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Both him and all his brothers unto reason.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter the Mayor and two Aldermen, below

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But in the night or in the time of war.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Takes his keys

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For Edward will defend the town and thee,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And all those friends that deign to follow me.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: March. Enter MONTGOMERY, with drum and soldiers

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: To help King Edward in his time of storm,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: As every loyal subject ought to do.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Our title to the crown and only claim

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Then fare you well, for I will hence again:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: I came to serve a king and not a duke.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: The drum begins to march

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhi le, and well debate

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: By what safe means the crown may be recoverd.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: What talk you of debating? in few words,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: If youll not here proclaim yourself our king,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Ill leave you to your fortune and be gone

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: To keep them back that come to succor you:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: When we grow stronger, then well make our claim:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Till then, tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Then be it as you will; for tis my right,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And Henry but usurps the diadem.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And now will I be Edwards champion.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaimd:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: England and France, and lord of Ireland,  and c.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And whosoeer gainsays King Edwards right,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: By this I challenge him to single fight.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Throws down his gauntlet

speaker: All
text_entry: Long live Edward the Fourth!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: If fortune serve me, Ill requite this kindness.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, for this night, lets harbour here in York;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And when the morning sun shall raise his car

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Above the border of this horizon,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well forward towards Warwick and his mates;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ah, froward Clarence! how evil it beseems thee

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet, as we may, well meet both thee and Warwick.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Come on, brave soldiers: doubt not of the day,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE VIII. London. The palace.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, WARWICK, MONTAGUE, CLARENCE, EXETER, and OXFORD

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath passd in safety through the narrow seas,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And with his troops doth march amain to London;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And many giddy people flock to him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lets levy men, and beat him back again.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: A little fire is quickly trodden out;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which, being sufferd, rivers cannot quench.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Those will I muster up: and thou, son Clarence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk, and in Kent,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The knights and gentlemen to come with thee:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Men well inclined to hear what thou commandst:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My sovereign, with the loving citizens,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Like to his island girt in with the ocean,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall rest in London till we come to him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Farewell, my sovereign.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troys true hope.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: In sign of truth, I kiss your highness hand.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Farewell, sweet lords: lets meet at Coventry.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt all but KING HENRY VI and EXETER

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here at the palace I will rest awhile.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Methinks the power that Edward hath in field

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Should not be able to encounter mine.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thats not my fear; my meed hath got me fame:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I have not stoppd mine ears to their demands,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor posted off their suits with slow delays;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My mildness hath allayd their swelling griefs,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I have not been desirous of their wealth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor much oppressd them with great subsidies.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor forward of revenge, though they much errd:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then why should they love Edward more than me?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And when the lion fawns upon the lamb,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The lamb will never cease to follow him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shout within. A Lancaster! A Lancaster!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Hark, hark, my lord! what shouts are these?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And once again proclaim us King of England.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now stops thy spring; my sea sha$l suck them dry,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And swell so much the higher by their ebb.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt some with KING HENRY VI

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Where peremptory Warwick now remains:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Away betimes, before his forces join,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And take the great-grown traitor unawares:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE I. Coventry.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter WARWICK, the Mayor of Coventry, two Messengers, and others upon the walls

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?

speaker: First Messenger
text_entry: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How far off is our brother Montague?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where is the post that came from Montague?

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: Enter SIR JOHN SOMERVILLE

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: At Southam I did leave him with his forces,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And do expect him here some two hours hence.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Drum heard

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Who should that be? belike, unlookd-for friends.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: March: flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced,

speaker: WARWICK
