text_entry: That we could hear no news of his repair?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And he shall pardon thee these outrages.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Confess who set thee up and pluckd thee own,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Call Warwick patron and be penitent?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I thought, at least, he would have said the king;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or did he make the jest against his will?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill do thee service for so good a gift.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why then tis mine, if but by Warwicks gift.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But Warwicks king is Edwards prisoner:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What is the body when the head is off?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The king was slily fingerd from the deck!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You left poor Henry at the Bishops palace,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, ten to one, youll meet him in the Tower.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And with the other fling it at thy face,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter OXFORD, with drum and colours

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: He and his forces enter the city

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The gates are open, let us enter too.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: So other foes may set upon our backs.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Stand we in good array; for they no doubt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Will issue out again and bid us battle:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: If not, the city being but of small defence,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter MONTAGUE with drum and colours

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: He and his forces enter the city

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The harder matchd, the greater victory:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter SOMERSET, with drum and colours

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: He and his forces enter the city

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have sold their lives unto the house of York;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of force enough to bid his brother battle;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With whom an upright zeal to right prevails

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: More than the nature of a brothers love!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt, if Warwick call.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Father of Warwick, know you what this means?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Taking his red rose out of his hat

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Look here, I throw my infamy at thee

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I will not ruinate my fathers house,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who gave his blood to lime the stones together,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And set up Lancaster. Why, trowst thou, Warwick,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To bend the fatal instruments of war

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Against his brother and his lawful king?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To keep that oath were more impiety

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Than Jephthahs, when he sacrificed his daughter.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I am so sorry for my trespass made

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That, to deserve well at my brothers hands,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: With resolution, wheresoeer I meet thee--

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As I will meet thee, if thou stir abroad--

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Alas, I am not coopd here for defence!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I will away towards Barnet presently,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt King Edward and his company. March. Warwick and his company follow

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE II. A field of battle near Barnet.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Alarum and excursions. Enter KING EDWARD IV, bringing forth WARWICK wounded

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For Warwick was a bug that feard us all.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That Warwicks bones may keep thine company.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exit

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend or foe,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That I must yield my body to the earth

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thus yields the cedar to the axes edge,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Under whose shade the ramping lion slept,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Whose top-branch overpeerd Joves spreading tree

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And kept low shrubs from winters powerful wind.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: These eyes, that now are dimmd with deaths black veil,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To search the secret treasons of the world:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were likend oft to kingly sepulchres;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And who durst mine when Warwick bent his brow?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Lo, now my glory smeard in dust and blood!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My parks, my walks, my manors that I had.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Even now forsake me, and of all my lands

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Is nothing left me but my bodys length.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, live we how we can, yet die we must.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter OXFORD and SOMERSET

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: We might recover all our loss again;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: The queen from France hath brought a puissant power:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Even now we heard the news: ah, couldst thou fly!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thou lovest me not; for, brother, if thou didst,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That glues my lips and will not let me speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breathed his last;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And said Commend me to my valiant brother.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And more he would have said, and more he spoke,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Which sounded like a clamour in a vault,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That mought not be distinguished; but at last

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: I well might hear, delivered with a groan,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: O, farewell, Warwick!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dies

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Away, away, to meet the queens great power!

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Here they bear away his body. Exeunt

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: SCENE III. Another part of the field.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV in triumph; with GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And we are graced with wreaths of victory.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But, in the midst of this bright-shining day,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That will encounter with our glorious sun,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ere he attain his easeful western bed:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And blow it to the source from whence it came:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: The very beams will dry those vapours up,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For every cloud engenders not a storm.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The queen is valued thirty thousand strong,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And Somerset, with Oxford fled to her:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If she have time to breathe be well assured

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: We are advertised by our loving friends

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: We, having now the best at Barnet field,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Will thither straight, for willingness rids way;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, as we march, our strength will be augmented

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: In every county as we go along.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Strike up the drum; cry Courage! and away.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE IV. Plains near Tewksbury.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: March. Enter QUEEN MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, SOMERSET, OXFORD, and soldiers

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Great lords, wise men neer sit and wail their loss,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What though the mast be now blown overboard,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And half our sailors swallowd in the flood?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet lives our pilot still. Ist meet that he

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With tearful eyes add water to the sea

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And give more strength to that which hath too much,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whiles, in his moan, the ship splits on the rock,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Which industry and courage might have saved?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Montague our topmost; what of him?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our slaughterd friends the tackles; what of these?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, is not Oxford here another anchor?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Somerset another goodly mast?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For once allowd the skilful pilots charge?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: We will not from the helm to sit and weep,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But keep our course, though the rough wind say no,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And what is Edward but ruthless sea?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: All these the enemies to our poor bark.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Say you can swim; alas, tis but a while!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or else you famish; thats a threefold death.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: This speak I, lords, to let you understand,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If case some one of you would fly from us,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That theres no hoped-for mercy with the brothers

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Should, if a coward heard her speak these words,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Infuse his breast with magnanimity

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I speak not this as doubting any here

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: For did I but suspect a fearful man

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: He should have leave to go away betimes,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Lest in our need he might infect another

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And make him of like spirit to himself.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: If any such be here--as God forbid!--

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Let him depart before we need his help.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Women and children of so high a courage,

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: And warriors faint! why, twere perpetual shame.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: O brave young prince! thy famous grandfather

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: To bear his image and renew his glories!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And he that will not fight for such a hope.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Go home to bed, and like the owl by day,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If he arise, be mockd and wonderd at.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: I thought no less: it is his policy

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: But hes deceived; we are in readiness.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: Flourish and march. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Which, by the heavens assistance and your strength,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I need not add more fuel to your fire,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My tears gainsay; for every word I speak,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ye see, I drink the water of mine eyes.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurpd,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His statutes cancelld and his treasure spent;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: You fight in justice: then, in Gods name, lords,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Be valiant and give signal to the fight.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Alarum. Retreat. Excursions. Exeunt

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE,  and soldiers; with QUEEN MARGARET, OXFORD, and SOMERSET, prisoners

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now here a period of tumultuous broils.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For Somerset, off with his guilty head.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.

speaker: OXFORD
text_entry: For my part, Ill not trouble thee with words.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Exeunt Oxford and Somerset, guarded

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: So part we sadly in this troublous world,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Is proclamation made, that who finds Edward

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Shall have a high reward, and he his life?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is: and lo, where youthful Edward comes!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter soldiers, with PRINCE EDWARD

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What! can so young a thorn begin to prick?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And all the trouble thou hast turnd me to?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Suppose that I am now my fathers mouth;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Which traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That you might still have worn the petticoat,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And neer have stoln the breech from Lancaster.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Let AEsop fable in a winters night;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: His currish riddles sort not with this place.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By heaven, brat, Ill plague ye for that word.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For Gods sake, take away this captive scold.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Untutord lad, thou art too malapert.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I know my duty; you are all undutiful:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And thou mis-shapen Dick, I tell ye all

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I am your better, traitors as ye are:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And thou usurpst my fathers right and mine.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Take that, thou likeness of this railer here.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Stabs him

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sprawlst thou? take that, to end thy agony.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stabs him

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And theres for twitting me with perjury.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Stabs him

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, kill me too!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Marry, and shall.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Offers to kill her

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why should she live, to fill the world with words?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What, doth she swoon? use means for her recovery.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill hence to London on a serious matter:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What? what?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The Tower, the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O Ned, sweet Ned! speak to thy mother, boy!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: They that stabbd Caesar shed no blood at all,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If this foul deed were by to equal it:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: He was a man; this, in respect, a child:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And men neer spend their fury on a child.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whats worse than murderer, that I may name it?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How sweet a plant have you untimely croppd!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: You have no children, butchers! if you had,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The thought of them would have stirrd up remorse:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But if you ever chance to have a child,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Look in his youth to have him so cut off

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As, deathmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Here sheathe thy sword, Ill pardon thee my death:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What, wilt thou not? then, Clarence, do it thou.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Twas sin before, but now tis charity.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What, wilt thou not? Where is that devils butcher,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hard-favourd Richard? Richard, where art thou?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou art not here: murder is thy alms-deed;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Petitioners for blood thou neer putst back.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: So come to you and yours, as to this Prince!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exit, led out forcibly

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Wheres Richard gone?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To London, all in post; and, as I guess,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To make a bloody supper in the Tower.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Hes sudden, if a thing comes in his head.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now march we hence: discharge the common sort

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: With pay and thanks, and lets away to London

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And see our gentle queen how well she fares:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: By this, I hope, she hath a son for me.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE VI. London. The Tower.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI and GLOUCESTER, with the Lieutenant, on the walls

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, my good lord:--my lord, I should say rather;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tis sin to flatter; good was little better:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Good Gloucester and good devil were alike,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And both preposterous; therefore, not good lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sirrah, leave us to ourselves: we must confer.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit Lieutenant

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And next his throat unto the butchers knife.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The thief doth fear each bush an officer.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The bird that hath been limed in a bush,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have now the fatal object in my eye

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where my poor young was limed, was caught and killd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, what a peevish fool was that of Crete,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That taught his son the office of a fowl!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: An yet, for all his wings, the fool was drownd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy father, Minos, that denied our course;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The sun that seard the wings of my sweet boy

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My breast can better brook thy daggers point

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than can my ears that tragic history.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But wherefore dost thou come? ist for my life?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thinkst thou I am an executioner?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A persecutor, I am sure, thou art:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If murdering innocents be executing,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, then thou art an executioner.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy son I killd for his presumption.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hadst thou been killd when first thou didst presume,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And thus I prophesy, that many a thousand,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And many an old mans sigh and many a widows,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And many an orphans water-standing eye--

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Men for their sons, wives for their husbands,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And orphans for their parents timeless death--

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The owl shriekd at thy birth,--an evil sign;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Dogs howld, and hideous tempest shook down trees;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The raven rookd her on the chimneys top,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And chattering pies in dismal discords sung.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy mother felt more than a mothers pain,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, yet brought forth less than a mothers hope,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To wit, an indigested and deformed lump,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To signify thou camest to bite the world:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, if the rest be true which I have heard,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou camest--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill hear no more: die, prophet in thy speech:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stabs him

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For this amongst the rest, was I ordaind.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, and for much more slaughter after this.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: God forgive my sins, and pardon thee!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Dies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See how my sword weeps for the poor kings death!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, may such purple tears be alway shed

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From those that wish the downfall of our house!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If any spark of life be yet remaining,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stabs him again

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I, that have neither pity, love, nor fear.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Indeed, tis true that Henry told me of;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For I have often heard my mother say

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I came into the world with my legs forward:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And seek their ruin that usurpd our right?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The midwife wonderd and the women cried

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And so I was; which plainly signified

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That I should snarl and bite and play the dog.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let hell make crookd my mind to answer it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have no brother, I am like no brother;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And this word love, which graybeards call divine,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be resident in men like one another

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And not in me: I am myself alone.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence, beware; thou keepst me from the light:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But I will sort a pitchy day for thee;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For I will buz abroad such prophecies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That Edward shall be fearful of his life,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then, to purge his fear, Ill be thy death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: King Henry and the prince his son are gone:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Counting myself but bad till I be best.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill throw thy body in another room

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit, with the body

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE VII. London. The palace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, QUEEN ELIZABETH,  CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, a Nurse with the young Prince, and Attendants

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Once more we sit in Englands royal throne,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Re-purchased with the blood of enemies.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What valiant foemen, like to autumns corn,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have we mowd down, in tops of all their pride!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renownd

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For hardy and undoubted champions;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Two Cliffords, as the father and the son,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And two Northumberlands; two braver men

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Neer spurrd their coursers at the trumpets sound;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That in their chains fetterd the kingly lion

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And made the forest tremble when they roard.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And made our footstool of security.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have in our armours watchd the winters night,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Went all afoot in summers scalding heat,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Ill blast his harvest, if your head were laid;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For yet I am not lookd on in the world.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This shoulder was ordaind so thick to heave;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And heave it shall some weight, or break my back:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Work thou the way,--and thou shalt execute.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: The duty that I owe unto your majesty

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprangst,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And cried all hail! when as he meant all harm.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now am I seated as my soul delights,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Having my countrys peace and brothers loves.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What will your grace have done with Margaret?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Reignier, her father, to the king of France

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Hath pawnd the Sicils and Jerusalem,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And hither have they sent it for her ransom.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Away with her, and waft her hence to France.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And now what rests but that we spend the time

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Such as befits the pleasure of the court?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Sound drums and trumpets! farewell sour annoy!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNTs palace.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And I in going, madam, weep oer my fathers death

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: anew: but I must attend his majestys command, to

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: whom I am now in ward, evermore in subjection.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: sir, a father: he that so generally is at all times

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: good must of necessity hold his virtue to you; whose

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: worthiness would stir it up where it wanted rather

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: than lack it where there is such abundance.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: What hope is there of his majestys amendment?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: He hath abandoned his physicians, madam; under whose

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: practises he hath persecuted time with hope, and

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: finds no other advantage in the process but only the

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: losing of hope by time.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: This young gentlewoman had a father,--O, that

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: had! how sad a passage tis!--whose skill was

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: almost as great as his honesty; had it stretched so

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: far, would have made nature immortal, and death

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: should have play for lack of work. Would, for the

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: kings sake, he were living! I think it would be

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: the death of the kings disease.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: How called you the man you speak of, madam?

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: He was excellent indeed, madam: the king very

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: lately spoke of him admiringly and mourningly: he

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: was skilful enough to have lived still, if knowledge

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: could be set up against mortality.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: A fistula, my lord.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I heard not of it before.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: her education promises; her dispositions she

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: commendations go with pity; they are virtues and

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: traitors too; in her they are the better for their

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: simpleness; she derives her honesty and achieves her goodness.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: in. The remembrance of her father never approaches

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: livelihood from her cheek. No more of this, Helena;

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: go to, no more; lest it be rather thought you affect

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: a sorrow than have it.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: excessive grief the enemy to the living.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: makes it soon mortal.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: How understand we that?

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: In manners, as in shape! thy blood and virtue

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Under thy own lifes key: be chequed for silence,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: But never taxd for speech. What heaven more will,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Fall on thy head! Farewell, my lord;

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Tis an unseasond courtier; good my lord,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Advise him.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: He cannot want the best

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: That shall attend his love.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: [To HELENA]  The best wishes that can be forged in

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: your thoughts be servants to you! Be comfortable

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: to my mother, your mistress, and make much of her.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold the credit of

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: your father.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Exeunt BERTRAM and LAFEU

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, were that all! I think not on my father;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And these great tears grace his remembrance more

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Than those I shed for him. What was he like?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I have forgot him: my imagination

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Carries no favour int but Bertrams.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am undone: there is no living, none,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If Bertram be away. Twere all one

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I should love a bright particular star

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And think to wed it, he is so above me:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: In his bright radiance and collateral light

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The hind that would be mated by the lion

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Must die for love. Twas pretty, though plague,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To see him every hour; to sit and draw

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: In our hearts table; heart too capable

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But now hes gone, and my idolatrous fancy

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Aside

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: One that goes with him: I love him for his sake;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And yet I know him a notorious liar,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That they take place, when virtues steely bones

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Look bleak i the cold wind: withal, full oft we see

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Save you, fair queen!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And you, monarch!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: No.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And no.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Are you meditating on virginity?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let me

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: may we barricado it against him?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Keep him out.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us some

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: warlike resistance.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: There is none: man, sitting down before you, will

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: undermine you and blow you up.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Bless our poor virginity from underminers and

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: blowers up! Is there no military policy, how

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: virgins might blow up men?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: blown up: marry, in blowing him down again, with

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the breach yourselves made, you lose your city. It

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: increase and there was never virgin got till

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: virginity was first lost. That you were made of is

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: metal to make virgins. Virginity by being once lost

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it is

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ever lost: tis too cold a companion; away with t!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I will stand for t a little, though therefore I die a virgin.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Theres little can be said in t; tis against the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: virginity murders itself and should be buried in

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but loose

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: byt: out with t! within ten year it will make

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: itself ten, which is a goodly increase; and the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: principal itself not much the worse: away with t!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Let me see: marry, ill, to like him that neer it

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: likes. Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: lying; the longer kept, the less worth: off with t

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: while tis vendible; answer the time of request.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: of fashion: richly suited, but unsuitable: just

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: like the brooch and the tooth-pick, which wear not

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: now. Your date is better in your pie and your

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: porridge than in your cheek; and your virginity,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: your old virginity, is like one of our French

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: withered pears, it looks ill, it eats drily; marry,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: tis a withered pear; it was formerly better;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: marry, yet tis a withered pear: will you anything with it?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Not my virginity yet [         ]

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: There shall your master have a thousand loves,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A mother and a mistress and a friend,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A phoenix, captain and an enemy,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: His humble ambition, proud humility,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he--

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I know not what he shall. God send him well!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The courts a learning place, and he is one--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What one, i faith?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I wish well. Tis pity--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Whats pity?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That wishing well had not a body int,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Might with effects of them follow our friends,

speaker: HELENA

text_entry: By sending me a letter? Read it again.

speaker: Steward
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: Steward
text_entry: I am Saint Jaques pilgrim, thither gone:

speaker: Steward
text_entry: Ambitious love hath so in me offended,

speaker: Steward
text_entry: That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,

speaker: Steward
text_entry: With sainted vow my faults to have amended.

speaker: Steward
text_entry: Write, write, that from the bloody course of war

speaker: Steward
text_entry: My dearest master, your dear son, may hie:

speaker: Steward
text_entry: Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far

speaker: Steward
text_entry: His name with zealous fervor sanctify:

speaker: Steward
text_entry: His taken labours bid him me forgive;

speaker: Steward
text_entry: I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth

speaker: Steward
text_entry: From courtly friends, with camping foes to live,

speaker: Steward
text_entry: Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth:

speaker: Steward
text_entry: He is too good and fair for death and me:

speaker: Steward
text_entry: Whom I myself embrace, to set him free.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!

text_entry: Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much,

text_entry: As letting her pass so: had I spoke with her,

text_entry: If I had given you this at over-night,

text_entry: What angel shall

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: To this unworthy husband of his wife;

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Let every word weigh heavy of her worth

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Dispatch the most convenient messenger:

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: When haply he shall hear that she is gone,

text_entry: He will return; and hope I may that she,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,

text_entry: To make distinction: provide this messenger:

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: My heart is heavy and mine age is weak;

speaker: COUNTESS
