text_entry: understand him, unless some one among us whom we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: must produce for an interpreter.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: No, sir, I warrant you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Een such as you speak to me.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He must think us some band of strangers i the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: adversarys entertainment. Now he hath a smack of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: know straight our purpose: choughs language,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: gabble enough, and good enough. As for you,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ten oclock: within these three hours twill be

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: time enough to go home. What shall I say I have

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: done? It must be a very plausive invention that

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: have of late knocked too often at my door. I find

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: daring the reports of my tongue.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This is the first truth that eer thine own tongue

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: was guilty of.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What the devil should move me to undertake the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: will say, Came you off with so little? and great

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ones I dare not give. Wherefore, whats the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: instance? Tongue, I must put you into a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: butter-womans mouth and buy myself another of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Bajazets mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: that he is?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We cannot afford you so.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: stratagem.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Twould not do.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Hardly serve.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: How deep?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Thirty fathom.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I would I had any drum of the enemys: I would swear

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I recovered it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: You shall hear one anon.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: A drum now of the enemys,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Alarum within

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

speaker: All
text_entry: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: They seize and blindfold him

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know you are the Muskos regiment:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And I shall lose my life for want of language;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Italian, or French, let him speak to me; Ill

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O!

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: The general is content to spare thee yet;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And, hoodwinkd as thou art, will lead thee on

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Something to save thy life.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O, let me live!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And all the secrets of our camp Ill show,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Their force, their purposes; nay, Ill speak that

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Which you will wonder at.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: But wilt thou faithfully?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: If I do not, damn me.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Acordo linta.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Come on; thou art granted space.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Till we do hear from them.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: Captain, I will.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: A will betray us all unto ourselves:

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Inform on that.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: So I will, sir.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Till then Ill keep him dark and safely lockd.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. Florence. The Widows house.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM and DIANA

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: No, my good lord, Diana.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Titled goddess;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: In your fine frame hath love no quality?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: If quick fire of youth light not your mind,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: You are no maiden, but a monument:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: When you are dead, you should be such a one

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: As you are now, for you are cold and stem;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And now you should be as your mother was

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: When your sweet self was got.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: She then was honest.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: So should you be.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: No:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My mother did but duty; such, my lord,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: As you owe to your wife.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: No more o that;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I prithee, do not strive against my vows:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I was compelld to her; but I love thee

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: By loves own sweet constraint, and will for ever

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Do thee all rights of service.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Ay, so you serve us

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And mock us with our bareness.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: How have I sworn!

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: But the plain single vow that is vowd true.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: What is not holy, that we swear not by,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: But take the Highst to witness: then, pray you, tell me,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: If I should swear by Gods great attributes,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When I did love you ill? This has no holding,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: To swear by him whom I protest to love,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That I will work against him: therefore your oaths

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Are words and poor conditions, but unseald,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: At least in my opinion.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Change it, change it;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And my integrity neer knew the crafts

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But give thyself unto my sick desires,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My love as it begins shall so persever.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I see that men make ropes in such a scarre

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That well forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Ill lend it thee, my dear; but have no power

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: To give it from me.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Will you not, my lord?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: It is an honour longing to our house,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Bequeathed down from many ancestors;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Which were the greatest obloquy i the world

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: In me to lose.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Mine honours such a ring:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My chastitys the jewel of our house,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Bequeathed down from many ancestors;

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Which were the greatest obloquy i the world

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Brings in the champion Honour on my part,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Against your vain assault.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Here, take my ring:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And Ill be bid by thee.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Ill order take my mother shall not hear.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Now will I charge you in the band of truth,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When you have conquerd my yet maiden bed,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When back again this ring shall be deliverd:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And on your finger in the night Ill put

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Another ring, that what in time proceeds

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: May token to the future our past deeds.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: You may so in the end.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My mother told me just how he would woo,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: As if she sat in s heart; she says all men

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When his wifes dead; therefore Ill lie with him

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Marry that will, I live and die a maid:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Only in this disguise I thinkt no sin

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: To cozen him that would unjustly win.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You have not given him his mothers letter?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I have delivered it an hour since: there is

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: something int that stings his nature; for on the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: reading it he changed almost into another man.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: When you have spoken it, tis dead, and I am the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: grave of it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: made in the unchaste composition.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: what things are we!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of all treasons, we still see them reveal

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: so he that in this action contrives against his own

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: nobility, in his proper stream oerflows himself.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters of

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: company to-night?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That approaches apace; I would gladly have him see

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his company anatomized, that he might take a measure

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: set this counterfeit.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: presence must be the whip of the other.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I hear there is an overture of peace.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travel

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: higher, or return again into France?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: of his council.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of his act.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: sanctimony she accomplished; and, there residing the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: now she sings in heaven.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: How is this justified?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: makes her story true, even to the point of her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: death: her death itself, which could not be her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: the rector of the place.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Hath the count all this intelligence?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: point, so to the full arming of the verity.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I am heartily sorry that hell be glad of this.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: here acquired for him shall at home be encountered

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: with a shame as ample.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: faults whipped them not; and our crimes would

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How now! wheres your master?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath

speaker: Servant
text_entry: taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next

speaker: Servant
text_entry: morning for France. The duke hath offered him

speaker: Servant
text_entry: letters of commendations to the king.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: They shall be no more than needful there, if they

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: were more than they can commend.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: They cannot be too sweet for the kings tartness.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Heres his lordship now.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How now, my lord! ist not after midnight?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: months length a-piece, by an abstract of success:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: and between these main parcels of dispatch effected

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: many nicer needs; the last was the greatest, but

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: that I have not ended yet.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: If the business be of any difficulty, and this

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: morning your departure hence, it requires haste of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: your lordship.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: me, like a double-meaning prophesier.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Bring him forth: has sat i the stocks all night,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: poor gallant knave.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurping

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: him. But to answer you as you would be understood;

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk: he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: this very instant disaster of his setting i the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: stocks: and what think you he hath confessed?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Nothing of me, has a?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: face: if your lordship be int, as I believe you

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: are, you must have the patience to hear it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: me: hush, hush!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: He calls for the tortures: what will you say

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: without em?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I will confess what I know without constraint: if

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Bosko chimurcho.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And truly, as I hope to live.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  First demand of him how many horse the

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: duke is strong. What say you to that?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Five or six thousand; but very weak and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and credit and as I hope to live.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Shall I set down your answer so?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Do: Ill take the sacrament ont, how and which way you will.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Alls one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Youre deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Parolles, the gallant militarist,--that was his own

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: phrase,--that had the whole theoric of war in the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his dagger.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: clean. nor believe he can have every thing in him

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: by wearing his apparel neatly.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, thats set down.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Five or six thousand horse, I said,-- I will say

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: true,--or thereabouts, set down, for Ill speak truth.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hes very near the truth in this.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But I con him no thanks fort, in the nature he

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: delivers it.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, thats set down.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I humbly thank you, sir: a truths a truth, the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: rogues are marvellous poor.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  Demand of him, of what strength they are

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: a-foot. What say you to that?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: poll; half of the which dare not shake snow from off

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: What shall be done to him?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, thats set down.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Reads

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumain

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: be i the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: with the duke; what his valour, honesty, and

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: possible, with well-weighing sums of gold, to

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: corrupt him to revolt. What say you to this? what

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: do you know of it?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the intergatories: demand them singly.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know him: a was a botchers prentice in Paris,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieves

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fool with child,--a dumb innocent, that could not

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: say him nay.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florences camp?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of your

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: lordship anon.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What is his reputation with the duke?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: out o the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Marry, well search.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: or it is upon a file with the dukes other letters

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: in my tent.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Here tis; heres a paper: shall I read it to you?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I do not know if it be it or no.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Our interpreter does it well.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Excellently.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  Dian, the counts a fool, and full of gold,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: That is not the dukes letter, sir; that is an

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Rousillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up again.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Nay, Ill read it first, by your favour.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My meaning int, I protest, was very honest in the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Damnable both-sides rogue!

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: After he scores, he never pays the score:

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: He neer pays after-debts, take it before;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss:

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: For count of this, the counts a fool, I know it,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Thine, as he vowed to thee in thine ear,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: PAROLLES.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: ins forehead.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: linguist and the armipotent soldier.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: hes a cat to me.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: I perceive, sir, by the generals looks, we shall be

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: fain to hang you.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: die; but that, my offences being many, I would

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: repent out the remainder of nature: let me live,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: sir, in a dungeon, i the stocks, or any where, so I may live.
